    private List<Task> tasks;
}

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Employee emp = session.get(Employee.class, 1); // Tasks are also loaded immediately
session.close();
System.out.println(emp.getTasks()); // ✅ No exception

3️⃣ Key Differences:

Feature Lazy Loading Eager Loading
Fetching Strategy Loads data only when needed Loads all data immediately
Performance Better for large datasets May cause performance issues
SQL Query Executes separate queries when accessing associations Executes a single query with JOINs
Risk of Exception May throw LazyInitializationException No exception
Best Use Case When associated data is rarely needed When associated data is frequently needed

⚠️ Best Practices:

  • Use **Lazy Loading** by default and fetch associations only when required.
  • Use **JOIN FETCH queries** to avoid LazyInitializationException.
  • Avoid **Eager Loading** for large data sets to prevent performance issues.

Definition: The Criteria API in Hibernate is used to create **dynamic, type-safe queries** programmatically without writing raw SQL or HQL.

1️⃣ Why Use Criteria API?

  • Provides a **type-safe and flexible** way to create queries.
  • Avoids SQL injection as it generates queries dynamically.
  • Useful for **complex queries with multiple conditions**.
  • Works well when query conditions are **built dynamically at runtime**.

2️⃣ Example: Basic Criteria Query

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
CriteriaBuilder cb = session.getCriteriaBuilder();
CriteriaQuery<Employee> cq = cb.createQuery(Employee.class);
Root<Employee> root = cq.from(Employee.class);
cq.select(root);
Query<Employee> query = session.createQuery(cq);
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

3️⃣ Applying Filters (WHERE Clause)

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
CriteriaBuilder cb = session.getCriteriaBuilder();
CriteriaQuery<Employee> cq = cb.createQuery(Employee.class);
Root<Employee> root = cq.from(Employee.class);
cq.select(root).where(cb.equal(root.get("department"), "IT"));
Query<Employee> query = session.createQuery(cq);
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

4️⃣ Criteria API vs HQL

Feature Criteria API HQL
Query Type Dynamic & Programmatic Static & String-based
Readability Better for complex queries Harder to maintain for large queries
Performance Depends on query complexity Generally faster for simple queries
Type Safety Yes (Prevents runtime errors) No (Prone to runtime errors)

⚠️ Best Practices:

  • Use **Criteria API** when building queries dynamically at runtime.
  • Use **HQL** when queries are static and performance is critical.
  • Combine **pagination** with Criteria API for better efficiency.

Definition: The @NamedQuery annotation in Hibernate is used to define **predefined, reusable HQL queries** at the entity level.

1️⃣ Why Use @NamedQuery?

  • Improves **code reusability** by defining queries once at the entity level.
  • Enhances **performance** since queries are compiled at startup.
  • Makes the code **cleaner and easier to manage**.

2️⃣ Example: Defining @NamedQuery

@Entity
@NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findByDepartment", 
            query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e WHERE e.department = :dept")
public class Employee {
    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
    private Long id;
    private String name;
    private String department;
}

3️⃣ Executing @NamedQuery in Hibernate

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Query<Employee> query = session.createNamedQuery("Employee.findByDepartment", Employee.class);
query.setParameter("dept", "IT");
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

4️⃣ Multiple Named Queries in @NamedQueries

@Entity
@NamedQueries({
    @NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findByName", query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e WHERE e.name = :name"),
    @NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findAll", query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e")
})
public class Employee {
    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
    private Long id;
    private String name;
    private String department;
}

5️⃣ Benefits of @NamedQuery

Feature @NamedQuery Dynamic HQL
Performance Faster (Precompiled at startup) Slower (Compiled at runtime)
Code Reusability Yes, defined at the entity level No, needs to be written repeatedly
Readability Improved (Defined once in the entity) Harder to manage in large projects
Maintainability Easy (Centralized query management) Complex (Scattered across codebase)

⚠️ Best Practices:

  • Use @NamedQuery for **frequently used, static queries**.
  • Avoid it when queries **need dynamic conditions** (Use Criteria API instead).
  • Keep query names **consistent and meaningful** for better readability.

Definition: These methods are used for **inserting and updating entities** in Hibernate, but they have different behaviors.

1️⃣ Difference Between save(), persist(), and merge()

Method Session or EntityManager Behavior Return Type Transaction Required?
save() Session Inserts a new record, assigns an identifier immediately. Serializable (ID) No (Executes immediately)
persist() EntityManager Makes entity managed but delays insert until commit. void Yes (Requires transaction)
merge() EntityManager Updates or inserts the entity (if detached). Managed entity Yes

2️⃣ Example: Using save() (Works in Hibernate 6)

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = session.beginTransaction();
Employee emp = new Employee();
emp.setName("John");
Serializable id = session.save(emp); // Immediately assigns ID
tx.commit();
session.close();

3️⃣ Example: Using persist() (Recommended in Hibernate 6 with JPA)

EntityManager entityManager = entityManagerFactory.createEntityManager();
entityManager.getTransaction().begin();
Employee emp = new Employee();
emp.setName("Alice");
entityManager.persist(emp); // Insert happens at commit
entityManager.getTransaction().commit();
entityManager.close();

4️⃣ Example: Using merge() (For updating detached entities)

EntityManager entityManager = entityManagerFactory.createEntityManager();
entityManager.getTransaction().begin();
Employee emp = entityManager.find(Employee.class, 1L); // Fetch existing entity
entityManager.detach(emp); // Make it detached
emp.setName("Updated Name");
Employee mergedEmp = entityManager.merge(emp); // Updates entity
entityManager.getTransaction().commit();
entityManager.close();

⚠️ Changes in Hibernate 6:

  • save() is still supported but generally replaced by **persist()** in JPA-based applications.
  • persist() is **preferred** in Hibernate 6 when using JPA EntityManager.
  • merge() is still necessary for updating **detached entities**.
  • **session.update()** has been **deprecated** in favor of merge().

🛠 Best Practices:

  • Use persist() when working with **new entities** in a managed transaction.
  • Use merge() when you need to **update a detached entity**.
  • Use save() only when working with **Hibernate Session** directly (not recommended in JPA).

Definition: Hibernate manages transactions internally using **JDBC transactions, JTA (Java Transaction API), or a custom transaction manager**.

1️⃣ Hibernate Transaction Management Workflow:

  • Hibernate uses the Transaction interface to **begin, commit, or rollback** transactions.
  • By default, Hibernate transactions are **auto-commit disabled**, requiring explicit commit.
  • It supports **JDBC transactions**, **JTA transactions**, and **Spring-managed transactions**.
  • Each transaction is bound to a **Session**, and multiple operations within the session participate in the same transaction.

2️⃣ Example: Hibernate Transaction with JDBC

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = null;
try {
    tx = session.beginTransaction();
    Employee emp = new Employee();
    emp.setName("John Doe");
    session.save(emp);
    tx.commit(); // ✅ Commit transaction
} catch (Exception e) {
    if (tx != null) tx.rollback(); // ❌ Rollback on failure
    e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
    session.close();
}

3️⃣ Example: Hibernate with Spring Transaction Management

@Service
public class EmployeeService {
    @Autowired
    private EntityManager entityManager;

    @Transactional // Spring manages transaction automatically
    public void saveEmployee(Employee emp) {
        entityManager.persist(emp); // Insert happens within the transaction
    }
}

⚠️ Key Points:

  • By default, **each Session manages its own transaction**.
  • If an exception occurs, Hibernate **automatically rolls back** the transaction if `commit()` is not called.
  • When using **Spring**, transactions are handled via `@Transactional`, and Spring manages commits and rollbacks.
  • In JTA (Java EE applications), Hibernate works with **distributed transactions** across multiple databases.

🛠 Best Practices:

  • Always use **transactions** when performing database operations.
  • Prefer @Transactional when using **Spring Boot** for simplified transaction management.
  • Use **try-catch-finally** to handle transaction rollback manually in plain Hibernate.
  • Avoid **long-running transactions**, as they can cause performance issues and lock database resources.

Definition: Hibernate performance tuning involves optimizing queries, caching, and session management to improve efficiency in high-load applications.

1️⃣ Enable Hibernate Caching:

  • Use **First-Level Cache (Session Cache)** – Enabled by default.
  • Use **Second-Level Cache (EhCache, Caffeine, Infinispan, etc.)** for frequently accessed data.
  • Enable **Query Cache** to avoid repeated execution of the same queries.

2️⃣ Optimize Hibernate Queries:

  • Use **JOIN FETCH** instead of multiple separate queries.
  • Avoid **N+1 Query Problem** using **@BatchSize** or **JOIN FETCH**.
  • Use **pagination (setMaxResults, setFirstResult)** for large datasets.

3️⃣ Use Connection Pooling:

  • Use **HikariCP** or **Apache DBCP** for efficient connection pooling.
  • Ensure the database connection pool is properly sized to handle concurrent requests.

4️⃣ Enable Batch Processing:

  • Batch inserts/updates using **JDBC batching** (`hibernate.jdbc.batch_size`).
  • Flush and clear the session periodically to avoid memory overload.

5️⃣ Lazy Loading vs Eager Loading:

  • Use **Lazy Loading (`fetch = FetchType.LAZY`)** to load data only when required.
  • Use **Eager Loading (`fetch = FetchType.EAGER`)** cautiously for frequently accessed relationships.

6️⃣ Example: Batch Processing in Hibernate

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = session.beginTransaction();
for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
    Employee emp = new Employee("Employee " + i);
    session.save(emp);
    if (i % 50 == 0) { // ✅ Flush & clear every 50 inserts
        session.flush();
        session.clear();
    }
}
tx.commit();
session.close();

7️⃣ Example: Connection Pooling with HikariCP

spring.datasource.hikari.minimumIdle=10
spring.datasource.hikari.maximumPoolSize=50
spring.datasource.hikari.idleTimeout=30000
spring.datasource.hikari.maxLifetime=1800000

⚠️ Key Points:

  • Use **caching** wisely to reduce database calls.
  • Avoid **loading large datasets into memory**, use pagination.
  • Optimize **batch processing** for bulk operations.
  • Monitor Hibernate queries with **SQL logs & performance profiling tools**.

🛠 Best Practices:

  • Use **@Transactional** effectively to manage transactions.
  • Avoid unnecessary **Session open/close operations** inside loops.
  • Use **Indexes in the database** to optimize query execution.
  • Regularly monitor **Hibernate statistics & slow queries**.

Definition: Docker is a containerization platform that allows applications, including Java applications, to run in isolated environments called **containers**.

1️⃣ Why Use Docker for Java Applications?

  • **Portability:** Run Java apps consistently across different environments (dev, test, production).
  • **Lightweight:** Uses fewer resources compared to virtual machines (VMs).
  • **Scalability:** Easily deploy and manage multiple instances using **Docker Compose** or **Kubernetes**.
  • **Dependency Management:** Ensures the same **JDK, libraries, and dependencies** in all environments.
  • **Faster Deployment:** Eliminates "works on my machine" issues.

2️⃣ How Docker Works with Java Applications?

  • Package your **Java application and dependencies** into a **Docker image**.
  • Run the **image as a container** on any system with Docker installed.
  • Use **Docker Compose** for managing multi-container Java applications.

3️⃣ Example: Dockerfile for a Spring Boot Java Application

# Use an official OpenJDK base image
FROM openjdk:17-jdk-slim

# Set working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy JAR file to container
COPY target/myapp.jar myapp.jar

# Expose port for the application
EXPOSE 8080

# Run the Java application
CMD ["java", "-jar", "myapp.jar"]

4️⃣ Build and Run Java Application in Docker

# Build the Docker image
docker build -t my-java-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 8080:8080 my-java-app

⚠️ Best Practices for Java & Docker:

  • Use **smaller base images** like `adoptopenjdk:17-jre-slim` to reduce size.
  • Optimize JVM options for Docker (`-XX:+UseContainerSupport`).
  • Use **multi-stage builds** to reduce final image size.
  • Store **configuration & secrets** outside the container (e.g., environment variables).

🛠 Advanced Features:

  • Use **Docker Compose** for managing multiple Java microservices.
  • Deploy containers to **Kubernetes (K8s)** for scaling.
  • Monitor Java applications using **Prometheus + Grafana** in Docker.

Definition: Kubernetes (K8s) is an **open-source container orchestration platform** that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

1️⃣ Key Features of Kubernetes:

  • **Automatic Scaling:** Adjusts the number of containers based on demand.
  • **Self-Healing:** Restarts failed containers and replaces unhealthy ones.
  • **Load Balancing:** Distributes traffic across containers for efficiency.
  • **Service Discovery:** Assigns stable DNS names to services.
  • **Rolling Updates:** Deploys new versions of applications without downtime.
  • **Multi-Cloud Support:** Runs applications across different cloud providers.

2️⃣ Kubernetes Architecture:

  • Master Node: Controls and manages the cluster.
  • Worker Nodes: Run the application containers.
  • Pods: The smallest deployable units in Kubernetes.
  • Deployments: Ensure the desired number of Pods run.
  • Services: Expose applications to the network.

3️⃣ Example: Kubernetes Deployment for a Java Spring Boot App

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: spring-boot-app
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: spring-boot-app
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: spring-boot-app
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: spring-boot-container
        image: my-spring-boot-app:latest
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8080

4️⃣ Kubernetes Commands:

# Apply deployment
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

# Get running pods
kubectl get pods

# Scale application
kubectl scale deployment spring-boot-app --replicas=5

⚠️ Best Practices for Kubernetes:

  • Use **ConfigMaps & Secrets** to manage configurations.
  • Implement **Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA)** for dynamic scaling.
  • Enable **monitoring with Prometheus & Grafana**.
  • Use **RBAC (Role-Based Access Control)** for security.

🛠 Advanced Features:

  • Manage microservices with **Kubernetes Service Mesh** (Istio).
  • Use **Helm Charts** for simplified application deployment.
  • Deploy across multiple clouds using **Kubernetes Federation**.

Definition: CI/CD (Continuous Integration & Continuous Deployment) automates building, testing, and deploying microservices, ensuring **fast & reliable releases**.

1️⃣ Key Steps in CI/CD for Microservices:

  • **Source Code Management:** Store microservices in Git repositories (GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket).
  • **Continuous Integration (CI):** Automate build & testing using Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or GitLab CI.
  • **Containerization:** Package services into Docker containers for consistent deployment.
  • **Continuous Deployment (CD):** Deploy microservices to Kubernetes or cloud platforms.
  • **Monitoring & Logging:** Use Prometheus, Grafana, ELK Stack for observability.

2️⃣ CI/CD Pipeline Example (Jenkins + Docker + Kubernetes)

pipeline {
    agent any
    stages {
        stage('Clone Repo') {
            steps {
                git 'https://github.com/user/microservice-repo.git'
            }
        }
        stage('Build & Test') {
            steps {
                sh 'mvn clean package'
                sh 'mvn test'
            }
        }
        stage('Build Docker Image') {
            steps {
                sh 'docker build -t my-microservice:latest .'
                sh 'docker tag my-microservice:latest myrepo/microservice:latest'
            }
        }
        stage('Push to Docker Hub') {
            steps {
                withDockerRegistry([credentialsId: 'docker-hub', url: '']) {
                    sh 'docker push myrepo/microservice:latest'
                }
            }
        }
        stage('Deploy to Kubernetes') {
            steps {
                sh 'kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml'
            }
        }
    }
}

3️⃣ Deployment Configuration (Kubernetes YAML)

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: microservice
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: microservice
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: microservice
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: microservice-container
        image: myrepo/microservice:latest
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8080

4️⃣ CI/CD Tools for Microservices:

  • **Version Control:** GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket
  • **CI/CD Pipelines:** Jenkins, GitHub Actions, GitLab CI/CD
  • **Containerization:** Docker
  • **Orchestration:** Kubernetes, OpenShift
  • **Monitoring:** Prometheus, Grafana, ELK Stack

⚠️ Best Practices:

  • Use **feature flags** for safe deployment.
  • Enable **blue-green or canary deployments** to reduce downtime.
  • Implement **role-based access control (RBAC)** for security.
  • Ensure **automated rollback** in case of failure.

🚀 Advanced CI/CD Enhancements:

  • Use **Helm Charts** to manage Kubernetes deployments.
  • Integrate **Chaos Engineering** for failure testing.
  • Implement **service mesh (Istio/Linkerd)** for traffic control.

Before Kubernetes: Different methods and tools were used to manage containerized applications.

  • 1️⃣ Manual Container Management (Docker CLI & Docker Compose)
    • How it worked: Used docker run commands & docker-compose.yml files.
    • Limitations: No auto-scaling, no self-healing, complex networking.
  • 2️⃣ Configuration Management Tools (Ansible, Chef, Puppet)
    • How it worked: Automated server & app deployment but lacked orchestration.
    • Limitations: No built-in scaling or dynamic load balancing.
  • 3️⃣ Container Orchestration Systems (Before Kubernetes)
Tool Description Limitations
Docker Swarm Lightweight orchestration from Docker. Limited auto-scaling & features compared to Kubernetes.
Apache Mesos Cluster manager with Marathon for containers. Complex setup, less adoption over time.
Amazon ECS AWS-specific container orchestration. Vendor lock-in (tied to AWS).

Why Kubernetes Replaced These?

  • ✅ Automated Scaling (Auto-scales based on CPU/memory usage).
  • ✅ Self-healing (Restarts failed containers automatically).
  • ✅ Service Discovery & Load Balancing (No manual networking needed).
  • ✅ Multi-cloud & Hybrid Support (Works on AWS, GCP, Azure, On-Prem).

Definition: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is a DevOps practice where infrastructure is provisioned and managed using code instead of manual processes.

Why Use IaC?

  • ✅ **Automation** – Reduces manual effort by automating infrastructure provisioning.
  • ✅ **Consistency** – Avoids configuration drift by maintaining a single source of truth.
  • ✅ **Scalability** – Enables easy scaling of infrastructure for large applications.
  • ✅ **Version Control** – Infrastructure configurations can be tracked using Git.
  • ✅ **Faster Deployments** – Reduces deployment time by quickly spinning up environments.

Popular IaC Tools:

Tool Description Use Case
Terraform Declarative IaC tool for managing cloud infrastructure. Works with AWS, Azure, GCP, Kubernetes.
CloudFormation AWS-specific IaC tool using YAML/JSON. Best for AWS-only infrastructure automation.
Ansible Configuration management and provisioning tool. Great for automating server configurations.
Pulumi IaC tool that allows writing configurations in programming languages. Best for developers preferring TypeScript, Python, or Go.

Example: Terraform Code for AWS EC2 Instance

# Define AWS Provider
provider "aws" {
  region = "us-east-1"
}

# Create an EC2 instance
resource "aws_instance" "example" {
  ami           = "ami-12345678"
  instance_type = "t2.micro"

  tags = {
    Name = "TerraformInstance"
  }
}

Conclusion: IaC simplifies infrastructure management, reduces human error, and ensures **faster, more efficient** deployments in a DevOps environment.

Overview: Spring Boot and Kubernetes together provide a **scalable, resilient, and automated** deployment environment for microservices.

Key Benefits:

  • ✅ **Scalability** – Kubernetes auto-scales Spring Boot applications based on demand.
  • ✅ **Self-Healing** – Automatically restarts failed pods, ensuring high availability.
  • ✅ **Service Discovery** – Kubernetes provides built-in service discovery for microservices.
  • ✅ **Configuration Management** – Externalized configuration using ConfigMaps and Secrets.
  • ✅ **Load Balancing** – Kubernetes balances traffic between application instances.
  • ✅ **CI/CD Integration** – Works well with Jenkins, GitHub Actions, and ArgoCD for automated deployments.

Example: Deploying a Spring Boot App in Kubernetes

# Deployment YAML for Spring Boot App
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: spring-boot-app
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: spring-boot
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: spring-boot
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: spring-boot-container
        image: myrepo/spring-boot-app:latest
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8080

Example: Kubernetes Service for Spring Boot

# Exposing Spring Boot app as a service
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: spring-boot-service
spec:
  type: LoadBalancer
  selector:
    app: spring-boot
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 80
      targetPort: 8080

Conclusion: Spring Boot with Kubernetes enables **cloud-native development**, ensuring reliability, scalability, and **faster deployments** with minimal manual intervention.

Overview: The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is an **engine** that runs Java bytecode and provides an abstraction over the underlying hardware.

Key Components of JVM:

  • 🔹 **ClassLoader** – Loads Java classes into memory.
  • 🔹 **Runtime Memory Areas**:
    • 📌 **Method Area** – Stores class metadata, static variables, and runtime constants.
    • 📌 **Heap** – Stores objects and their instance variables.
    • 📌 **Stack** – Stores method execution frames and local variables.
    • 📌 **PC Register** – Holds the current instruction being executed.
    • 📌 **Native Method Stack** – Manages native method calls.
  • 🔹 **Execution Engine**:
    • ⚙️ **Interpreter** – Converts bytecode to machine code line by line.
    • ⚙️ **JIT (Just-In-Time) Compiler** – Converts frequently used bytecode into native code for better performance.
    • ⚙️ **Garbage Collector** – Automatically deallocates unused objects in the heap.
  • 🔹 **Java Native Interface (JNI)** – Allows Java code to interact with native libraries.

JVM Architecture Diagram:

Example Code: JVM loads and executes Java bytecode.

public class JVMExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("JVM Architecture Demo!");
    }
}

Conclusion: JVM provides **platform independence** by converting Java bytecode into machine-specific instructions, making Java a **"write once, run anywhere"** language.

Overview: Hibernate uses **JDBC or JTA (Java Transaction API)** to manage transactions. It ensures **ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability)** properties in database operations.

Transaction Handling in Hibernate:

  • 🔹 **Session & Transaction API** – Hibernate transactions are handled via the `Session` and `Transaction` interfaces.
  • 🔹 **Commit & Rollback** – Operations are committed if successful, or rolled back if an exception occurs.
  • 🔹 **Automatic & Manual Transactions**:
    • ✅ **Automatic** – Managed by frameworks like Spring (via `@Transactional`).
    • ✅ **Manual** – Explicitly controlled via Hibernate API.

Example: Manual Transaction Management

Session session = HibernateUtil.getSessionFactory().openSession();
Transaction transaction = null;
try {
    transaction = session.beginTransaction();
    
    // Perform database operations
    User user = new User("John Doe");
    session.save(user);
    
    transaction.commit(); // Commit transaction
} catch (Exception e) {
    if (transaction != null) {
        transaction.rollback(); // Rollback on error
    }
    e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
    session.close();
}

Example: Transaction Management using Spring

@Service
public class UserService {
    @Autowired
    private UserRepository userRepository;

    @Transactional
    public void createUser(String name) {
        User user = new User(name);
        userRepository.save(user); // Transaction is handled automatically
    }
}

Key Takeaways:

  • 🔹 Use **manual transactions** when fine-grained control is needed.
  • 🔹 Use **Spring @Transactional** for automatic transaction management.
  • 🔹 Always **commit or rollback** transactions to ensure data integrity.

Conclusion: Hibernate provides **flexible transaction handling**, allowing both manual and automatic management via Spring or native Hibernate API.

Overview: **CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)** and **Event Sourcing** are two architectural patterns often used together but serve different purposes.

1️⃣ CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation):

  • 🔹 Separates the **read** (Query) and **write** (Command) operations into different models.
  • 🔹 Improves **scalability** and **performance** by optimizing reads and writes separately.
  • 🔹 Helps in **distributed systems** where read and write workloads differ significantly.
  • 🔹 Example: A microservices architecture where **commands update the database**, and **queries fetch from a read-optimized cache**.

2️⃣ Event Sourcing:

  • 🔹 Instead of storing only the latest state, **stores a sequence of events** that led to the current state.
  • 🔹 Enables **rebuilding past states** by replaying events.
  • 🔹 Useful for **audit logs, temporal queries, and debugging**.
  • 🔹 Example: A banking system that stores **"Money Deposited"** and **"Money Withdrawn"** events instead of just an account balance.

🆚 Key Differences:

Aspect CQRS Event Sourcing
Purpose Separates read and write models Stores all changes as events
Storage Stores only the latest state Keeps a full history of changes
Use Case Optimizing performance & scalability Ensuring auditability & historical analysis
State Recovery Depends on database snapshots Reconstructs state by replaying events

Example: Implementing CQRS with Event Sourcing

// Event definition
class OrderPlacedEvent {
    private String orderId;
    private String product;
    private int quantity;
}

// Command for placing an order
class PlaceOrderCommand {
    private String product;
    private int quantity;
}

// Handling the command
class OrderService {
    public void handle(PlaceOrderCommand command) {
        // Save event to Event Store
        eventStore.save(new OrderPlacedEvent(UUID.randomUUID().toString(), command.getProduct(), command.getQuantity()));
    }
}

// Querying the read model
class OrderQueryService {
    public Order getOrder(String orderId) {
        return orderRepository.findById(orderId);
    }
}

Key Takeaways:

  • 🔹 **CQRS optimizes performance** by separating read and write models.
  • 🔹 **Event Sourcing ensures a full history** of state changes for traceability.
  • 🔹 Both can be used **together** to achieve **high scalability and event-driven systems**.

Conclusion: While **CQRS improves scalability**, **Event Sourcing provides historical state tracking**. They complement each other in distributed and event-driven architectures.

Overview: Docker helps package, distribute, and run Java applications in isolated containers, ensuring consistency across different environments.

1️⃣ Why Use Docker for Java Applications?

  • 🔹 Ensures **environment consistency** across development, testing, and production.
  • 🔹 **Easier deployment** without worrying about dependencies.
  • 🔹 **Efficient resource usage** with containerized microservices.
  • 🔹 Supports **scalability** and **CI/CD automation**.

2️⃣ Steps to Containerize a Java Application:

  • 🔹 Create a **Dockerfile** to define how your Java app should be built and run.
  • 🔹 Build the Docker image using **docker build**.
  • 🔹 Run the container using **docker run**.

3️⃣ Example: Dockerizing a Spring Boot App

# Dockerfile
FROM openjdk:17-jdk-slim
WORKDIR /app
COPY target/myapp.jar app.jar
EXPOSE 8080
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

Commands to Build & Run:

# Build the Docker image
docker build -t my-java-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 8080:8080 my-java-app

4️⃣ Running Java Containers in Kubernetes:

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: java-app
spec:
  replicas: 2
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: java-app
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: java-app
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: java-app
          image: my-java-app
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8080

5️⃣ Benefits of Running Java in Docker:

  • 🔹 **Faster deployment** with pre-built images.
  • 🔹 **Simplified dependency management**.
  • 🔹 **Better resource utilization** with container orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes).

Conclusion: Docker simplifies Java application deployment, making it portable, scalable, and easy to manage across different environments.

Overview: In Java, exceptions are organized into a hierarchical structure under the Throwable class. This hierarchy helps in structured exception handling.

1️⃣ Exception Hierarchy Diagram:

          Throwable
             ├── Error (Unchecked)
             │   ├── StackOverflowError
             │   ├── OutOfMemoryError
             │   ├── VirtualMachineError
             │   └── AssertionError
             │
             └── Exception (Checked)
                 ├── IOException
                 │   ├── FileNotFoundException
                 │   ├── EOFException
                 │
                 ├── SQLException
                 ├── InterruptedException
                 ├── ReflectiveOperationException
                 ├── RuntimeException (Unchecked)
                     ├── NullPointerException
                     ├── ArithmeticException
                     ├── IndexOutOfBoundsException
                     ├── IllegalArgumentException
                     └── ClassCastException

2️⃣ Key Categories:

  • 🔹 Checked Exceptions: Must be handled using try-catch or declared with throws.
  • 🔹 Unchecked Exceptions: Occur due to programming errors and don’t require explicit handling.
  • 🔹 Errors: Indicate serious issues like JVM crashes (should not be caught).

3️⃣ Example: Handling Checked & Unchecked Exceptions

import java.io.*;

public class ExceptionExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            FileReader file = new FileReader("test.txt"); // Checked Exception
        } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
            System.out.println("File not found: " + e.getMessage());
        }

        // Unchecked Exception Example
        int[] arr = {1, 2, 3};
        System.out.println(arr[5]); // Throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
    }
}

4️⃣ Best Practices:

  • 🔹 Always handle **checked exceptions** properly.
  • 🔹 Avoid catching **unchecked exceptions**, fix the root cause instead.
  • 🔹 Use **custom exceptions** when built-in exceptions are not enough.

Conclusion: Understanding Java’s exception hierarchy helps in writing robust and error-free code by handling exceptions efficiently.

Overview: Microservices Architecture is a design pattern where an application is structured as a collection of small, independent services that communicate over a network.

1️⃣ Microservices Architecture Diagram:

2️⃣ Key Components:

  • 🔹 API Gateway: Centralized entry point for external requests.
  • 🔹 Microservices: Independent services handling specific business functionalities.
  • 🔹 Database per Service: Each service has its own dedicated database to ensure data consistency.
  • 🔹 Service Discovery: Helps in locating services dynamically.
  • 🔹 Load Balancer: Distributes traffic across multiple instances of a service.
  • 🔹 Centralized Logging & Monitoring: Observability tools like ELK stack, Prometheus, and Grafana.

3️⃣ Benefits of Microservices:

  • ✅ Scalability: Individual services can scale independently.
  • ✅ Fault Isolation: Failure in one service doesn’t bring down the entire system.
  • ✅ Technology Flexibility: Each microservice can use different technologies.
  • ✅ Faster Deployment: Smaller codebases allow for quicker updates.

4️⃣ Example: Implementing a Simple Microservice

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public ResponseEntity<User> getUser(@PathVariable Long id) {
        return ResponseEntity.ok(new User(id, "John Doe", "john@example.com"));
    }
}

Conclusion: Microservices architecture enhances scalability, fault tolerance, and flexibility, making it ideal for modern cloud-based applications.

Overview: Spring Boot provides a robust and scalable framework for building microservices. Below is the recommended tech stack for developing a microservices-based system.

1️⃣ Core Components:

  • 🔹 Spring Boot: Provides an easy way to create microservices with embedded servers.
  • 🔹 Spring Cloud: Helps with service discovery, configuration management, resilience, and distributed tracing.
  • 🔹 Spring Security: Handles authentication and authorization.
  • 🔹 Spring Data: Simplifies database access with JPA and NoSQL support.

2️⃣ Microservices Infrastructure Tools:

  • ✅ API Gateway: Spring Cloud Gateway or Netflix Zuul for routing requests.
  • ✅ Service Discovery: Spring Cloud Eureka or Consul for dynamic service registration.
  • ✅ Configuration Management: Spring Cloud Config for centralized configuration.
  • ✅ Load Balancing: Spring Cloud LoadBalancer or Ribbon.
  • ✅ Circuit Breaker: Resilience4j (formerly Hystrix) for fault tolerance.
  • ✅ Logging & Monitoring: ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Prometheus + Grafana.
  • ✅ Tracing: Spring Cloud Sleuth + Zipkin for distributed tracing.

3️⃣ Database Options:

  • 📌 Relational: MySQL, PostgreSQL (via Spring Data JPA)
  • 📌 NoSQL: MongoDB, Redis, Cassandra (via Spring Data NoSQL)

4️⃣ Example: Creating a Simple Microservice

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/orders")
public class OrderController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public ResponseEntity<Order> getOrder(@PathVariable Long id) {
        return ResponseEntity.ok(new Order(id, "Laptop", 75000));
    }
}

Conclusion: The Spring Boot tech stack for microservices enables scalable, fault-tolerant, and cloud-native applications.

Overview: The Saga Pattern is a mechanism for handling distributed transactions in a microservices architecture. It ensures data consistency across services using a sequence of compensating transactions.

1️⃣ Two Types of Saga Implementation:

  • 🔹 Choreography: Each service performs a transaction and publishes an event that triggers the next service.
  • 🔹 Orchestration: A central orchestrator coordinates the transactions across microservices.

2️⃣ Example: Order Processing with Saga (Orchestration)

We will implement a simple **Order Service** where orders are processed through multiple microservices: OrderService, PaymentService, and InventoryService.

3️⃣ Implementation Steps:

  • ✅ **Order Service**: Creates an order and starts the saga.
  • ✅ **Payment Service**: Processes the payment.
  • ✅ **Inventory Service**: Checks item availability.
  • ✅ **Compensating Transactions**: If any step fails, rollback actions are triggered.

4️⃣ Order Service (Starting the Saga):

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/orders")
public class OrderController {
    @Autowired private OrderService orderService;

    @PostMapping
    public ResponseEntity<String> createOrder(@RequestBody OrderRequest request) {
        String orderId = orderService.createOrder(request);
        return ResponseEntity.ok("Order placed successfully! ID: " + orderId);
    }
}

5️⃣ Saga Orchestrator: (Coordinating the steps)

@Service
public class OrderSagaOrchestrator {
    @Autowired private PaymentService paymentService;
    @Autowired private InventoryService inventoryService;

    public void processOrder(Order order) {
        try {
            paymentService.processPayment(order);
            inventoryService.checkStock(order);
            System.out.println("✅ Order completed successfully!");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.out.println("❌ Order failed. Initiating rollback...");
            paymentService.refundPayment(order);
        }
    }
}

6️⃣ Payment Service:

@Service
public class PaymentService {
    public void processPayment(Order order) {
        System.out.println("💳 Processing payment for Order ID: " + order.getId());
    }
    public void refundPayment(Order order) {
        System.out.println("🔄 Refunding payment for Order ID: " + order.getId());
    }
}

7️⃣ Inventory Service:

@Service
public class InventoryService {
    public void checkStock(Order order) {
        System.out.println("📦 Checking stock for Order ID: " + order.getId());
    }
}

Conclusion: The Saga pattern ensures data consistency in microservices by handling transactions in steps and rolling back if failures occur.

Overview: Microservices architecture allows building applications as a collection of small, independent services that communicate with each other. This approach enhances scalability, flexibility, and maintainability.

Key Benefits:

  • ✅ Scalability: Each microservice can scale independently based on demand, optimizing resource usage.
  • ✅ Faster Development & Deployment: Teams can develop, test, and deploy microservices separately, leading to faster release cycles.
  • ✅ Technology Flexibility: Different microservices can use different programming languages, frameworks, and databases as per their specific needs.
  • ✅ Improved Fault Isolation: A failure in one microservice does not necessarily bring down the entire system, improving resilience.
  • ✅ Better Maintainability: Code is modular and easier to understand, debug, and maintain.
  • ✅ Enhanced Security: Services can be isolated with different access controls, reducing attack risks.
  • ✅ Continuous Integration & Deployment (CI/CD): Microservices enable automated deployments with minimal downtime.

Example: E-Commerce Microservices

// Order Microservice - Handles order creation
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/orders")
public class OrderController {
    @Autowired private OrderService orderService;

    @PostMapping
    public ResponseEntity createOrder(@RequestBody OrderRequest request) {
        return ResponseEntity.ok(orderService.createOrder(request));
    }
}
// Payment Microservice - Processes payments
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/payments")
public class PaymentController {
    @Autowired private PaymentService paymentService;

    @PostMapping
    public ResponseEntity processPayment(@RequestBody PaymentRequest request) {
        return ResponseEntity.ok(paymentService.processPayment(request));
    }
}

Business Use Case: Netflix

  • Netflix uses **microservices** to manage different functionalities like user authentication, video streaming, recommendations, and billing.
  • Each feature runs as an independent microservice, ensuring **fault tolerance** and **high availability**.
  • If the recommendation service fails, it won’t affect video streaming, ensuring a smooth user experience.

Conclusion: Microservices architecture is ideal for **scalable, resilient, and high-performance applications**, making it a popular choice for modern software development.

Overview: While microservices offer flexibility and scalability, they also introduce complexities and challenges.

Key Drawbacks:

  • ⚠️ Increased Complexity: Managing multiple services, databases, and interactions requires careful design.
  • ⚠️ Higher Latency: Communication between services over the network introduces latency compared to in-memory calls in monoliths.
  • ⚠️ Difficult Debugging & Troubleshooting: Tracing issues across multiple services is more challenging than in a monolithic system.
  • ⚠️ Data Management Challenges: Ensuring consistency and handling distributed transactions is complex.
  • ⚠️ Operational Overhead: Requires DevOps automation for service deployment, monitoring, and orchestration.
  • ⚠️ Security Concerns: More services mean more attack surfaces, requiring strong security measures.
  • ⚠️ Dependency Management: Handling API versions and dependencies across services can be complicated.

Example: Distributed Transaction Challenge

// A distributed transaction across Order and Payment Microservices
@Transactional
public void placeOrder(OrderRequest request) {
    orderService.createOrder(request);
    paymentService.processPayment(request.getPaymentDetails()); // If this fails, rollback needed
}

Conclusion: While microservices provide many benefits, they also introduce challenges that require strong architectural patterns like **API Gateways, Service Discovery, Distributed Tracing, and Circuit Breakers**.

What is Agile?

  • 🔹 Agile is a **software development methodology** focused on **iterative development, collaboration, and customer feedback**.
  • 🔹 It helps teams **deliver working software faster** by breaking work into **small, manageable increments**.
  • 🔹 Agile frameworks include **Scrum, Kanban, XP (Extreme Programming), and SAFe**.

Main Principles of Agile (from Agile Manifesto):

  • ✅ **Customer Satisfaction** – Deliver **valuable software early and continuously**.
  • ✅ **Embrace Change** – Adapt to **changing requirements**, even late in development.
  • ✅ **Frequent Delivery** – Release working software at **short intervals** (e.g., every 2 weeks in Scrum).
  • ✅ **Collaboration** – Close **interaction between developers, business teams, and customers**.
  • ✅ **Motivated Individuals** – Support a **self-organizing, motivated team**.
  • ✅ **Face-to-Face Communication** – Encourage direct communication for **faster problem-solving**.
  • ✅ **Working Software is the Measure of Progress** – Functionality is more important than documentation.
  • ✅ **Sustainable Development** – Maintain a **steady, continuous pace** for long-term efficiency.
  • ✅ **Technical Excellence** – Prioritize **high-quality coding, design, and architecture**.
  • ✅ **Simplicity** – Focus on the **most essential work**, avoiding unnecessary complexity.
  • ✅ **Self-Organizing Teams** – Empower teams to **make decisions and innovate**.
  • ✅ **Regular Reflection & Improvement** – Teams continuously **review their performance and adjust**.

Example: Agile in Software Development

// Example of an Agile Scrum Workflow
Sprint 1: Develop User Login Feature
Sprint 2: Implement Payment Integration
Sprint 3: Add Order Tracking System
Sprint 4: Enhance UI & Performance

Business Use Case: Amazon

  • Amazon uses Agile methodologies to **release new features rapidly**.
  • They iterate quickly based on **customer feedback**, improving **search algorithms, recommendation engines, and UI updates**.
  • Scrum teams deliver **incremental updates**, ensuring continuous innovation.

Conclusion: Agile helps **businesses stay competitive** by delivering **quality software faster** while **adapting to customer needs dynamically**.

Agile is based on 12 key principles from the Agile Manifesto:

  • ✅ **Customer Satisfaction** – Deliver **valuable software early and continuously**.
  • ✅ **Embrace Change** – Adapt to **changing requirements**, even late in development.
  • ✅ **Frequent Delivery** – Release working software at **short intervals** (e.g., every 2 weeks in Scrum).
  • ✅ **Collaboration** – Close **interaction between developers, business teams, and customers**.
  • ✅ **Motivated Individuals** – Support a **self-organizing, motivated team**.
  • ✅ **Face-to-Face Communication** – Encourage direct communication for **faster problem-solving**.
  • ✅ **Working Software is the Measure of Progress** – Functionality is more important than documentation.
  • ✅ **Sustainable Development** – Maintain a **steady, continuous pace** for long-term efficiency.
  • ✅ **Technical Excellence** – Prioritize **high-quality coding, design, and architecture**.
  • ✅ **Simplicity** – Focus on the **most essential work**, avoiding unnecessary complexity.
  • ✅ **Self-Organizing Teams** – Empower teams to **make decisions and innovate**.
  • ✅ **Regular Reflection & Improvement** – Teams continuously **review their performance and adjust**.

Example: Agile Development Process

// Example Agile Workflow in a Sprint
Sprint 1: Develop User Authentication
Sprint 2: Implement Payment Gateway
Sprint 3: Add Order Tracking System
Sprint 4: Optimize UI & Performance

Business Use Case: Spotify

  • Spotify uses Agile to **release new features iteratively**.
  • They break down projects into **small, manageable parts** and gather continuous user feedback.
  • Scrum and Kanban help them maintain **fast development cycles**.

Conclusion: Agile fosters **flexibility, collaboration, and rapid development** for **high-quality, customer-centric software**.

Scrum vs. Kanban vs. XP – Agile Frameworks

  • Scrum: A structured Agile framework based on **fixed-length iterations (Sprints)**.
  • Kanban: A flexible Agile framework focused on **continuous flow and work-in-progress limits**.
  • Extreme Programming (XP): An Agile methodology emphasizing **high-quality software development through frequent releases and best coding practices**.

Key Differences:

Feature Scrum Kanban Extreme Programming (XP)
Process Type Iterative (Sprint-based) Continuous Flow Iterative + Engineering Focus
Roles Scrum Master, Product Owner, Team No defined roles No defined roles, but focuses on developers
Work Planning Work planned before each Sprint Work continuously pulled from backlog Similar to Scrum, with daily releases
Work Progress Tracking Burn-down/Burn-up charts Kanban board Velocity, Unit Tests, Pair Programming
Best For Teams that prefer structured workflows Teams that need flexibility & continuous flow Teams needing extreme code quality & fast iterations

Example Use Cases:

  • 📌 Scrum: Used by companies like **Salesforce & Microsoft** for feature-driven development.
  • 📌 Kanban: Used in **IT support & operations** where continuous task flow is required.
  • 📌 XP: Used in **high-quality software teams** where **test-driven development (TDD)** and continuous feedback are critical.

Conclusion: ✅ **Scrum is best for structured teams following fixed sprints**. ✅ **Kanban is great for continuous, flexible workflows**. ✅ **XP is perfect for teams focused on clean, high-quality code with rapid releases**.

Scrum Artifacts represent key information that Scrum teams use to **track progress and deliver value efficiently**.

  • 1️⃣ Product Backlog:
    • A **prioritized list of features, enhancements, and bug fixes** maintained by the Product Owner.
    • Contains everything needed to improve the product.
    • Continuously refined through **Backlog Grooming**.
  • 2️⃣ Sprint Backlog:
    • A **subset of the Product Backlog** that the team commits to completing within the Sprint.
    • Includes **tasks, user stories, and technical items** for the Sprint.
    • Provides **visibility into work-in-progress**.
  • 3️⃣ Increment:
    • The sum of **all completed Product Backlog Items (PBIs)** at the end of a Sprint.
    • Represents a **potentially shippable product**.
    • Must meet the **Definition of Done (DoD)** before being released.

📌 Additional Supporting Artifacts:

  • 4️⃣ Definition of Done (DoD):
    • A shared agreement on what makes a backlog item **"done"**.
    • Ensures quality by defining **code reviews, testing, and documentation requirements**.
  • 5️⃣ Burndown Chart:
    • A graphical **representation of work completed vs. work remaining**.
    • Helps track the **team's progress towards the Sprint goal**.

Example Use Case: 📌 **A software company uses the Product Backlog to prioritize features, the Sprint Backlog to plan short-term work, and the Increment to track the product's evolution.**

Conclusion: ✅ **Product Backlog** → What needs to be built? ✅ **Sprint Backlog** → What will be completed this Sprint? ✅ **Increment** → What has been completed so far? ✅ **DoD & Burndown Charts** → Ensure transparency & progress tracking.

Scope Creep refers to uncontrolled changes or continuous expansion of a project's scope **without proper review and approval**.

🔹 Causes of Scope Creep:

  • Unclear project requirements.
  • Frequent changes from stakeholders.
  • Poor backlog management.
  • Lack of proper prioritization.
  • No strong Definition of Done (DoD).

🛡️ Strategies to Handle Scope Creep in Agile:

  • 1️⃣ Strong Product Backlog Management:
    • Ensure all new changes go through **prioritization** before being added to the backlog.
    • Use **MoSCoW (Must-have, Should-have, Could-have, Won’t-have)** prioritization.
  • 2️⃣ Define Clear Acceptance Criteria & DoD:
    • Clearly define when a task is **complete** to avoid endless modifications.
    • Use **well-defined user stories and acceptance criteria**.
  • 3️⃣ Frequent Stakeholder Communication:
    • Conduct **regular sprint reviews and backlog refinement** to align expectations.
    • Encourage feedback **within iterations** instead of mid-sprint changes.
  • 4️⃣ Use Timeboxing & Fixed Sprints:
    • Set **fixed Sprint durations (1-4 weeks)** to limit excessive changes.
    • Any new requirement should be added to **future sprints** instead of disrupting the current one.
  • 5️⃣ Educate the Team & Clients:
    • Help stakeholders understand **Agile principles** and why scope creep affects delivery.
    • Use Agile tools like **JIRA, Azure DevOps, or Trello** to maintain transparency.

📌 Example Use Case:

🚀 A software company developing a mobile app notices that stakeholders keep adding **new features mid-sprint**. 👉 To control this, they implement **MoSCoW prioritization**, conduct **backlog grooming sessions**, and agree that new changes will only be discussed **before a new Sprint starts**.

💡 Conclusion:

  • ✅ Maintain a **well-prioritized backlog**.
  • ✅ Implement **strong acceptance criteria & DoD**.
  • ✅ Keep **stakeholders involved regularly** but control mid-sprint changes.
  • ✅ Use **timeboxing to limit excessive requests**.
  • ✅ **Educate teams & clients** on Agile best practices.

Definition of Done (DoD) vs. Acceptance Criteria: Both **DoD** and **Acceptance Criteria** ensure quality and completeness in Agile development, but they serve different purposes.

🔹 Definition of Done (DoD):

  • ✅ A **standardized checklist** applied to **all user stories or tasks**.
  • ✅ Ensures that work meets **organizational or team-wide quality** before release.
  • ✅ **Common for all user stories & tasks** in a project.
  • ✅ Typically includes:
    • Code is written, reviewed, and merged.
    • Unit tests and integration tests passed.
    • No critical bugs remain.
    • Deployed to staging/QA environment.
    • Meets performance and security standards.
    • Documentation is updated.

🔹 Acceptance Criteria:

  • ✅ **Specific conditions** that must be met for a **single user story** to be accepted.
  • ✅ Defines **functional & business requirements** for the story.
  • ✅ Custom to each user story and written by the **Product Owner/BA**.
  • ✅ Example for a "Login feature":
    • 🚀 User enters valid credentials and logs in successfully.
    • 🚀 If login fails, an appropriate error message is shown.
    • 🚀 Password field hides input (masked characters).

📌 Key Differences:

Aspect Definition of Done (DoD) Acceptance Criteria
Purpose Ensures overall quality of a task Defines when a specific user story is complete
Scope Applies to **all user stories** Unique to **each user story**
Who Defines It? Team (Developers, QA, Scrum Master) Product Owner, Business Analyst
Example Code must be reviewed, tested, and deployed User must see an error if login fails

💡 Conclusion:

  • 📌 **Definition of Done** ensures overall quality before release.
  • 📌 **Acceptance Criteria** define what makes a **specific user story** acceptable.
  • 📌 Both work together to maintain **clarity and quality** in Agile projects.

Measuring Success in Agile Projects:

Agile success is **not just about delivering features**—it’s about delivering value, improving efficiency, and maintaining customer satisfaction.

🔹 Key Agile Success Metrics:

  • 🚀 Business Value Delivered – Are we meeting customer and business goals?
  • 📈 Velocity – How many story points or user stories are completed per sprint?
  • 📊 Lead Time & Cycle Time – How long does it take to deliver a feature from idea to production?
  • 📉 Defect Rate – How many bugs/issues are found during and after development?
  • 💬 Customer & Stakeholder Satisfaction – Are users happy with the delivered product?
  • 🔄 Sprint Predictability – Are we completing planned work consistently?
  • 🤝 Team Collaboration & Engagement – Are teams working efficiently together?

📌 Detailed Explanation:

Metric Description Why It Matters?
Velocity Measures the number of story points completed in a sprint. Helps in **capacity planning & forecasting**.
Lead Time Time taken from idea creation to production. Tracks **efficiency in delivering features**.
Defect Rate Tracks the number of bugs reported in a release. Ensures **code quality & stability**.
Customer Satisfaction Measured using CSAT or NPS surveys. Ensures we are **delivering value** to end users.
Sprint Predictability Percentage of committed work completed. Tracks **team efficiency & reliability**.

💡 Conclusion:

  • 📌 Agile success is **not just about speed** but **value delivery**.
  • 📌 **Business impact > Story points completed.**
  • 📌 Regularly track **velocity, quality, and customer feedback** for continuous improvement.

Measuring Success in Agile Projects:

Agile success is **not just about delivering features**—it’s about delivering value, improving efficiency, and maintaining customer satisfaction.

🔹 Key Agile Success Metrics:

  • 🚀 Business Value Delivered – Are we meeting customer and business goals?
  • 📈 Velocity – How many story points or user stories are completed per sprint?
  • 📊 Lead Time & Cycle Time – How long does it take to deliver a feature from idea to production?
  • 📉 Defect Rate – How many bugs/issues are found during and after development?
  • 💬 Customer & Stakeholder Satisfaction – Are users happy with the delivered product?
  • 🔄 Sprint Predictability – Are we completing planned work consistently?
  • 🤝 Team Collaboration & Engagement – Are teams working efficiently together?

📌 Detailed Explanation:

Metric Description Why It Matters?
Velocity Measures the number of story points completed in a sprint. Helps in **capacity planning & forecasting**.
Lead Time Time taken from idea creation to production. Tracks **efficiency in delivering features**.
Defect Rate Tracks the number of bugs reported in a release. Ensures **code quality & stability**.
Customer Satisfaction Measured using CSAT or NPS surveys. Ensures we are **delivering value** to end users.
Sprint Predictability Percentage of committed work completed. Tracks **team efficiency & reliability**.

💡 Conclusion:

  • 📌 Agile success is **not just about speed** but **value delivery**.
  • 📌 **Business impact > Story points completed.**
  • 📌 Regularly track **velocity, quality, and customer feedback** for continuous improvement.

🔹 Agile Estimation Overview:

Agile teams estimate work to **understand effort, complexity, and time required** for user stories and tasks. Unlike traditional time-based estimates, Agile uses **relative estimation** techniques.

📌 Common Estimation Techniques:

  • 🎴 Planning Poker: Team members use Fibonacci numbers (1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13...) to estimate tasks.
  • ⚖️ T-Shirt Sizing: Work is categorized as **XS, S, M, L, XL** based on complexity.
  • 📊 Story Points: A relative measure of effort required to complete a story.
  • 🛠️ Affinity Estimation: Similar user stories are grouped together based on size and effort.
  • 🕰️ Ideal Days: Estimation based on the number of uninterrupted days required to complete a task.
  • 📉 Bucket System: Stories are placed in pre-defined buckets (1, 2, 5, 10, 20 points) for faster estimation.

📝 Example: Planning Poker in Action

// Example of Planning Poker estimation
Scrum Master: "How many story points for this feature?"
Developer 1: "I vote 5 points."
Developer 2: "I think it's 8 points."
Team Discusses... → Final consensus: 6 points

🚀 Benefits of Agile Estimation:

  • ✔️ Encourages **team collaboration** and shared understanding.
  • ✔️ Focuses on **relative complexity** rather than absolute time.
  • ✔️ Helps in **predicting velocity** for sprint planning.
  • ✔️ Reduces **overestimation & underestimation risks**.

💡 Conclusion:

  • 📌 Agile estimation is **not about exact hours** but **relative effort**.
  • 📌 Techniques like **Planning Poker, T-Shirt Sizing, and Story Points** make estimation effective.
  • 📌 Continuous refinement improves estimation accuracy over time.

📌 Scrum Master Overview:

The **Scrum Master** is responsible for ensuring the **Scrum framework** is understood and followed by the team. They act as a **coach, facilitator, and servant leader** to help the team achieve high performance.

🔹 Key Responsibilities of a Scrum Master:

  • 📅 Facilitating Scrum Events: Organizes and moderates **Daily Standups, Sprint Planning, Sprint Review, and Retrospectives**.
  • 🛠️ Removing Impediments: Identifies and resolves blockers that slow down the team.
  • 📈 Coaching & Mentoring: Guides the team on **Scrum principles, Agile mindset, and best practices**.
  • 🤝 Protecting the Team: Shields the team from distractions and unnecessary interruptions.
  • 🎯 Enhancing Collaboration: Improves communication between **developers, Product Owner, and stakeholders**.
  • 🚀 Continuous Improvement: Encourages feedback, promotes experimentation, and helps the team **increase velocity**.
  • 📊 Tracking & Reporting: Monitors team progress using **burn-down charts, velocity tracking, and sprint reports**.

💡 Example: Resolving a Blocker

// Developer faces an issue with deployment
Developer: "I'm stuck with this production bug."
Scrum Master: "Let's escalate this to DevOps and find a solution."
// Scrum Master facilitates resolution and ensures sprint progress

🚀 Why is a Scrum Master Important?

  • ✔️ Ensures the **team follows Agile best practices**.
  • ✔️ Helps the team **deliver high-quality products efficiently**.
  • ✔️ Acts as a **bridge between technical teams and business stakeholders**.
  • ✔️ Creates a **culture of trust, transparency, and continuous learning**.

🔚 Conclusion:

  • 📌 A **Scrum Master is not a manager**, but a **servant leader**.
  • 📌 Their primary role is to **enable team success by removing obstacles**.
  • 📌 **Good Scrum Masters** foster **self-organizing, high-performing teams**.

📌 Overview:

TreeSet is a part of Java's **Collection Framework** and implements the **NavigableSet** interface. It is a sorted set based on **Red-Black Tree**, ensuring elements are always stored in **ascending order**.

🔹 Key Features of TreeSet:

  • 📖 **Stores unique elements** (No duplicates allowed).
  • 🚀 **Automatically sorts elements** in natural order (or custom Comparator).
  • ⏳ **O(log n) time complexity** for add, remove, and contains operations.
  • ❌ **Does not allow `null` values** (Throws `NullPointerException`).
  • 🛠️ **Implements NavigableSet**: Supports methods like `higher()`, `lower()`, `ceiling()`, and `floor()`.

💡 Example Usage:

import java.util.TreeSet;

public class TreeSetExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        TreeSet<Integer> numbers = new TreeSet<>();
        numbers.add(50);
        numbers.add(20);
        numbers.add(40);
        numbers.add(10);
        
        System.out.println("TreeSet: " + numbers); // Output: [10, 20, 40, 50]
        System.out.println("First Element: " + numbers.first()); // Output: 10
        System.out.println("Last Element: " + numbers.last()); // Output: 50
    }
}

🔹 Key Methods in TreeSet:

  • 📌 **`first()` / `last()`** → Returns the first/last element.
  • 📌 **`higher(E e)` / `lower(E e)`** → Finds next higher/lower element.
  • 📌 **`ceiling(E e)` / `floor(E e)`** → Finds smallest >= or largest <= element.
  • 📌 **`pollFirst()` / `pollLast()`** → Retrieves and removes first/last element.
  • 📌 **`descendingSet()`** → Returns elements in descending order.

⚠️ Limitations of TreeSet:

  • ⏳ **Slower than HashSet** due to sorting (`O(log n)` operations).
  • ❌ **Cannot store `null` values**.
  • 📊 **Sorting overhead** can impact performance in large datasets.

🔚 Conclusion:

  • ✔️ **TreeSet is best** when you need a **sorted, unique collection**.
  • ✔️ Use **HashSet for faster operations** if sorting is not required.
  • ✔️ Implements **NavigableSet**, making range-based queries easy.

TreeSet: A NavigableSet implementation based on a Red-Black Tree.

  • Maintains elements in **sorted order** (ascending by default).
  • Does **not allow duplicates**.
  • Not **thread-safe** (use `Collections.synchronizedSortedSet()` for synchronization).
  • Elements must be **Comparable** or use a **Comparator**.
  • Offers **logarithmic time complexity (O(log n))** for basic operations.
  • Supports **methods like first(), last(), higher(), lower(), ceiling(), and floor()**.

Example:

import java.util.TreeSet;

public class TreeSetExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        TreeSet set = new TreeSet<>();
        set.add(10);
        set.add(5);
        set.add(20);
        set.add(15);
        
        System.out.println(set); // Output: [5, 10, 15, 20]
        System.out.println("First: " + set.first());  // 5
        System.out.println("Last: " + set.last());    // 20
    }
}

Race Condition: A concurrency issue where multiple threads access shared resources and produce unpredictable results.

  • Occurs when two or more threads access a **shared variable** without proper synchronization.
  • Leads to **data inconsistency** and unpredictable behavior.
  • Happens when one thread is **reading or modifying a variable** while another thread is modifying it simultaneously.
  • Common in **multi-threaded environments** when using **non-thread-safe** classes.

Example of Race Condition:

class Counter {
    private int count = 0;
    
    public void increment() {
        count++; // Not thread-safe
    }
    
    public int getCount() {
        return count;
    }
}

public class RaceConditionExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Counter counter = new Counter();

        Runnable task = () -> {
            for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
                counter.increment();
            }
        };

        Thread t1 = new Thread(task);
        Thread t2 = new Thread(task);
        t1.start();
        t2.start();

        try {
            t1.join();
            t2.join();
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        System.out.println("Final Count: " + counter.getCount()); // Unexpected result
    }
}

Ways to Prevent Race Conditions:

  • Using synchronized keyword: Ensures only one thread modifies shared data at a time.
  • Using Locks (ReentrantLock): Provides fine-grained control over synchronization.
  • Using Atomic Variables: Use `AtomicInteger`, `AtomicLong`, etc., for thread-safe operations.
  • Using volatile (in specific cases): Ensures visibility of changes across threads.

Example Using synchronized:

class SafeCounter {
    private int count = 0;

    public synchronized void increment() {
        count++; // Thread-safe
    }

    public synchronized int getCount() {
        return count;
    }
}

Efficient File I/O: Java provides multiple ways to read and write files efficiently.

Best Approaches for File Handling:

  • Buffered Streams: Uses `BufferedReader` and `BufferedWriter` for optimized reading and writing.
  • NIO (New I/O) with Buffers: Uses `FileChannel` and `ByteBuffer` for high-performance file operations.
  • Memory-Mapped Files: Uses `MappedByteBuffer` for large file processing.
  • Files API (Java 7+): Uses `Files.readAllLines()` or `Files.write()` for simple file operations.

Example: Using BufferedReader (Efficient for Large Files)

import java.io.*;

public class BufferedFileReaderExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("file.txt"))) {
            String line;
            while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
                System.out.println(line);
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

Example: Using NIO (FileChannel and ByteBuffer)

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
import java.nio.channels.FileChannel;
import java.nio.file.*;

public class NIOFileReader {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open(Paths.get("file.txt"), StandardOpenOption.READ)) {
            ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(1024);
            while (channel.read(buffer) > 0) {
                buffer.flip();
                while (buffer.hasRemaining()) {
                    System.out.print((char) buffer.get());
                }
                buffer.clear();
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

Example: Using Memory-Mapped Files (Best for Large Files)

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.MappedByteBuffer;
import java.nio.channels.FileChannel;
import java.nio.file.*;

public class MemoryMappedFileExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open(Paths.get("file.txt"), StandardOpenOption.READ)) {
            MappedByteBuffer buffer = channel.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, channel.size());
            for (int i = 0; i < buffer.limit(); i++) {
                System.out.print((char) buffer.get());
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

Best Practices for Efficient File I/O:

  • Use **BufferedReader and BufferedWriter** for text-based file operations.
  • Use **NIO (FileChannel and ByteBuffer)** for large file processing.
  • Use **Memory-Mapped Files** for extremely large files to improve performance.
  • Use **Files API** (`Files.readAllLines()`, `Files.write()`) for simple file handling.

Issue with parallelStream() and Exceptions:

  • Java `parallelStream()` runs tasks in parallel using the **ForkJoinPool**.
  • If an exception occurs in one thread, it **does not stop other threads** from executing.
  • Handling exceptions in a parallel stream can be tricky because it does not propagate exceptions in a straightforward way.

Solution 1: Using try-catch Inside forEach

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;

public class ParallelStreamExceptionHandling {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5);

        numbers.parallelStream().forEach(num -> {
            try {
                System.out.println(10 / num); // May cause division by zero
            } catch (ArithmeticException e) {
                System.out.println("Exception: " + e.getMessage());
            }
        });
    }
}

Solution 2: Using map() with Exception Handling

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

public class ParallelStreamTryCatch {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5);

        List results = numbers.parallelStream()
            .map(num -> {
                try {
                    return "Result: " + (10 / num);
                } catch (ArithmeticException e) {
                    return "Exception: " + e.getMessage();
                }
            })
            .collect(Collectors.toList());

        results.forEach(System.out::println);
    }
}

Solution 3: Custom Wrapper for Exception Handling

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.function.Function;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

public class ParallelStreamWithWrapper {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5);

        List results = numbers.parallelStream()
            .map(handleException(num -> "Result: " + (10 / num), ArithmeticException.class))
            .collect(Collectors.toList());

        results.forEach(System.out::println);
    }

    public static  Function handleException(Function function, Class exceptionClass) {
        return value -> {
            try {
                return function.apply(value);
            } catch (Exception e) {
                if (exceptionClass.isInstance(e)) {
                    return (R) ("Exception: " + e.getMessage());
                }
                throw e;
            }
        };
    }
}

Key Takeaways:

  • Use **try-catch inside forEach** to handle exceptions in parallelStream().
  • Use **map() to transform results** while handling exceptions.
  • Use a **custom wrapper function** to handle exceptions generically.
  • Be cautious, as parallel streams **do not stop execution** on an exception.

Using synchronized (this):

  • It locks the **current object instance** (`this`) to prevent concurrent access.
  • Only **one thread** can execute the synchronized block at a time **for that instance**.
  • Other threads calling synchronized blocks **on the same instance** will be blocked.
  • Threads calling **synchronized methods** or blocks on **a different instance** will not be affected.

Example: Using synchronized (this)

class SharedResource {
    public void printNumbers() {
        synchronized (this) {
            for (int i = 1; i <= 5; i++) {
                System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " - " + i);
                try { Thread.sleep(500); } catch (InterruptedException e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
            }
        }
    }
}

public class SyncExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SharedResource obj = new SharedResource();

        Thread t1 = new Thread(obj::printNumbers, "Thread-1");
        Thread t2 = new Thread(obj::printNumbers, "Thread-2");

        t1.start();
        t2.start();
    }
}

Output Behavior:

  • Since synchronized (this) locks the **same instance**, **only one thread at a time** will execute the block.
  • The other thread will **wait** until the first thread completes.

What If You Use synchronized (someOtherObject)?

  • Locking on another object allows multiple threads to execute this object's methods **simultaneously**.
  • Useful when you want to synchronize based on **a shared external object** rather than the instance itself.

Difference Between synchronized (this) and synchronized method:

Feature synchronized (this) synchronized method
Scope Locks only the block Locks the entire method
Flexibility Allows finer control (can lock part of a method) Locks the whole method
Locking Object Locks the current instance (this) Locks the instance implicitly

Key Takeaways:

  • synchronized (this) locks only the block inside the method.
  • It allows **more flexibility** compared to synchronizing the entire method.
  • It still blocks other threads trying to enter **another synchronized block/method** on the **same instance**.
  • For class-level locking, use synchronized (ClassName.class) instead.

Explanation: When you use synchronized (this) inside a non-static method, it locks the current instance of the object.

  • Only one thread can enter the synchronized block for that instance at a time.
  • If multiple threads operate on different instances, they won’t block each other.
  • Other non-synchronized methods of the same instance can still run concurrently.

Example:

class SharedResource {
    public void printNumbers() {
        synchronized (this) { // Locks the current instance
            for (int i = 1; i <= 5; i++) {
                System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " - " + i);
                try { Thread.sleep(500); } catch (InterruptedException e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
            }
        }
    }
}

public class SyncExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SharedResource obj1 = new SharedResource();
        SharedResource obj2 = new SharedResource();

        Thread t1 = new Thread(obj1::printNumbers, "Thread-1");
        Thread t2 = new Thread(obj1::printNumbers, "Thread-2");
        Thread t3 = new Thread(obj2::printNumbers, "Thread-3");

        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        t3.start();
    }
}

Expected Behavior:

  • Thread-1 and Thread-2 share obj1, so they execute sequentially.
  • Thread-3 operates on a separate instance (obj2), so it runs concurrently.

Key Takeaways:

  • synchronized (this) ensures that only one thread can execute the synchronized block per instance.
  • Different instances of the class do not interfere with each other.
  • For class-level locking, use synchronized (ClassName.class) instead.

Default Behavior: @ManyToMany is LAZY by default in Hibernate.

  • Lazy loading means associated collections are not fetched until explicitly accessed.
  • Can be changed to FetchType.EAGER if needed, but this may cause performance issues.

Example:

@Entity
class Student {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String name;
    
    @ManyToMany(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    private List courses;
}

@Entity
class Course {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String title;
    
    @ManyToMany(mappedBy = "courses", fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    private List students;
}

Default Fetch Type: In Hibernate, the default fetch type for @ManyToMany is LAZY. This means related entities are not loaded until explicitly accessed.

Example: A many-to-many relationship between Student and Course entities. 

@Entity
class Student {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String name;

    @ManyToMany
    @JoinTable(
        name = "student_course",
        joinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "student_id"),
        inverseJoinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "course_id")
    )
    private List<Course> courses;
}

@Entity
class Course {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String title;

    @ManyToMany(mappedBy = "courses")
    private List<Student> students;
}

Explanation:

  • The @ManyToMany association is lazy-loaded by default.
  • The @JoinTable annotation defines the join table.
  • The mappedBy attribute in Course indicates the owning side is Student.

Lazy Loading in Action:

Student student = entityManager.find(Student.class, 1L);
System.out.println(student.getName()); // Works
System.out.println(student.getCourses()); // Triggers a LazyInitializationException if session is closed

Default Behavior: By default, @ManyToMany uses LAZY fetching, meaning related entities are loaded only when accessed.

To Make it EAGER: Use fetch = FetchType.EAGER explicitly in the annotation.

Example: Updating the Student entity to use EAGER fetching.

@Entity
class Student {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String name;

    @ManyToMany(fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @JoinTable(
        name = "student_course",
        joinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "student_id"),
        inverseJoinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "course_id")
    )
    private List<Course> courses;
}

Explanation:

  • Adding fetch = FetchType.EAGER forces Hibernate to load associated Course entities immediately.
  • Reduces LazyInitializationException risks, but may cause performance issues if too many related entities exist.

EAGER Loading in Action:

Student student = entityManager.find(Student.class, 1L);
System.out.println(student.getCourses()); // Now loads courses immediately

Definition: @NamedQuery is used to define a static, reusable HQL (Hibernate Query Language) query with a specific name.

Why Use @NamedQuery?

  • Improves performance by pre-compiling queries.
  • Enhances code reusability and maintains clean code.
  • Avoids hardcoding queries inside Java code.

Example: Defining and using a NamedQuery.

@Entity
@NamedQuery(name = "Student.findByName", query = "SELECT s FROM Student s WHERE s.name = :name")
class Student {
    @Id @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    private String name;
}

How to Use the Named Query:

TypedQuery<Student> query = entityManager.createNamedQuery("Student.findByName", Student.class);
query.setParameter("name", "John");
List<Student> students = query.getResultList();

Explanation:

  • The query SELECT s FROM Student s WHERE s.name = :name is pre-defined in the @NamedQuery.
  • Using createNamedQuery(), we execute it with parameters.
  • Enhances maintainability by centralizing queries.

Definition: The save() method in JpaRepository is used to insert or update an entity in the database.

How It Works?

  • If the entity has a null or non-existing id, it performs an INSERT operation.
  • If the entity has an existing id, it performs an UPDATE operation.
  • Uses the EntityManager internally to persist or merge the entity.

Example: Saving a new Employee

@Entity
class Employee {
    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
    private Long id;
    private String name;
    private String department;
    
    // Getters and Setters
}
@Repository
public interface EmployeeRepository extends JpaRepository<Employee, Long> { }
@Service
public class EmployeeService {
    @Autowired
    private EmployeeRepository employeeRepository;

    public void saveEmployee() {
        Employee emp = new Employee();
        emp.setName("John Doe");
        emp.setDepartment("IT");

        Employee savedEmployee = employeeRepository.save(emp); // INSERT if ID is null
        System.out.println("Saved Employee ID: " + savedEmployee.getId());
    }
}

Behavior:

  • If id is null → INSERT new record.
  • If id exists → UPDATE existing record.
  • Uses Transactional support from Spring.

Changes in Spring Boot 3:

  • Spring Boot 3 uses Hibernate 6, which optimizes the save() method.
  • Now relies on merge() only if needed instead of always merging detached entities.
  • Better support for immutability and records in Java 17.

Definition:

  • Access Specifiers: Control the visibility of a class, method, or variable from other classes.
